How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:What is important in a car when you are driving fast and come to a light? Choices:  A: stripes B: seat belts C: breaks to help stop D: tires E: radios<n><n>### Response:		If you come to a light and are driving fast and need to stop then you should press the breaks.<n><n>#### A<n><n>### If A is important<n><n>### The answer does not mention B<n>### So A is correct<n>#### A<n><n>#### E<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input<n>Which should you eat faster if you are hungry? Choices: A: an apple B: a carrot<n>C: a banana D: a pear E: peas<n><n>### Response <n>Input:A carrot has more calories than a banana. This proves that you should eat a carrot instead of bananas. A carrot is one of the best fruits.  Additionally, a banana has a lot of sugar.<n><n>#### A-E<n><n>Answer: A <n><n>### Input Which is closer to the Earth, the sun, or the moon?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Input  The sun is closer to the Earth than the Moon.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:When a newborn's eyes open for the first time it will be the first time the ever? Choices:  A: tear up B: see light C: fill with tears D: be happy E: glass over<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demostration for response:<n><n>#### 2. The answer is A: tear up<n>

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:The movie had many a song and dance, it was a what? Choices:  A: bollywood B: record C: musical D: jukebox E: napster<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n><p style='float:left;'>C: musical</p><n><p style='font-size:24px;margin-left:10px;'>The movie had many a <u style='color:yellow'>song</u> and dance, <u style='color:#006600;'>it was a what?</u></p><n>```<n><n>### Input<n><n><p style='clear: left;'>A: bollywood. B: record. C: musical, D: jukebox. E: the movie had a big what?</p><n><n><p style="float: right;<n>    font-size: 48px;font-weight: 800;line-height: 136%; text-align: left;margin: 20px 10px;"><n>C: musical</p></p><n><n>### Response<n><p style='margin-left: 200px; margin-top: -20px; float:left; width:270px;'><n><p style='color:#06f'><i style='float:left'>D</i><b>[C]:</b> musical</p><n><n>## Solution:<n>```<n>{{< highlight python >}}<n>def function_name(function_argument):<n><n>    input = "the movie had many a song"<n>    choices = ["bollywood", "record", "musical", "jukebox"]<n><n>    for i in choice:<n>        choices.remove(i)<n>    if i.lower() == function_argument.lower():<n>        print(i.fontsize,i.marginleft,i+":",i.fontweight,i.lineheight)<n>    else:<n>        print(i+" doesn't match this input string.")<n>{{< / highlight >}}<n><n>function_name("D: musical")<n>{{< / highlight python >}}<n><n>{% include disqus.html %} <n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:Many containers full of goods are unloaded where after their long sea journey Choices:  A: port B: cargo ship C: refrigerator D: food E: lorry<n><n>### Response:		A.<n>### Rationales:<n>- Ships are called cargo ships, so Choice B cannot hold. <n>- Shipping containers are called reefers or refrigerators, so Choice C cannot hold. <n><n>### Input:"Our family of eight will always stay at one of the three resort hotels near the seaside." Choices:  A. hotel B. beach C. ocean D. resort E. sea<n><n>### Rational:<n>A family of 8 people are usually staying at a 2/4 (2/4 room). <n>"one of..." is singular, so "beach", "sea", or "ocean" cannot hold. <n>"resort" is a noun (a place to relax) which means "Hotel". <n>So, "one of the 3 resort hotels" means hotel. <n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:An attempt to confirm an applicant's reference would fail if the reference does what? Choices:  A: question B: dispute C: deny D: contradict E: refuse<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Reason:<n>#### A: Question: The application asks for the applicant's references and the reference gives the applicant's work history.<n>If the application has a work history section then this isn't a dispute but perhaps more of an agreement,<n>If the reference disputes the work history they could say for example the applicant is lying and giving the name of an entire project instead of the project that they worked on.<n><n>#### B: Dispute: The application asks for 3 references, the reference questions the validity of the application.<n>The reference questions the valid application but the reference actually does agree to the work history,<n>if the reference questions if the applicant was actually hired by the organization listed on the application then that would be a dispute but otherwise yes the applicant and the reference have agreed to the work history.<n><n>#### C: Deny: The application asks for work and educational history and the applicant never went to college<n>Therefore the reference denies the work of the applicant, they don't agree to any work history as this applicant never went to school.<n><n>#### D: Contradict: The application asks for three references and the applicant never worked with them.<n>The three references contradict the applicant in that the reference did not work with the applicant,<n>the two that contradict the rest do not agree to any work history with the applicant this means that the reference is refusing any work relationship the applicant has had.<n><n>#### E: Refuse: The application asks for two references and the applicant has no current or former work history.<n>Without any current or former work history that the reference can agree to the reference has no information.<n>The reference cannot agree to a work history and so the applicant is not given a job because the applicant cannot provide any work history for the applicant to look at and agree to.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:Where is a microphone boom likely to be covering a stock market event? Choices:  A: new york B: concert C: tv studio D: gig E: recording studio<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A<n><n>### rationales:<n>  We know that microphones are very delicate instruments, and therefore they are covered with many layers of protection to protect it from the impact of any outside force or sudden movements. That’s why most microphone booms are found at any live events, especially any stage performances or television studio events. The microphone boom is used to prevent the microphone from hitting any other objects near it. <n><n>#### B<n><n>### rationaleses: <n>  When you attend concerts, it is the performers who are singing and dancing on stage that catch your attention as the best-looking, and sometimes best-performing, part of the event. However, there is another critical aspect of a concert; a microphone boom. The performance won't be well recorded if the performers are moving around and sometimes not in the best position. If the microphone is being shaky, that will also affect the audio quality. Therefore, the microphone is mounted on the stage where it can track all movements of the performers. <n><n>#### C<n><n>### rationalesis:<n>  Microphone booms are often built into your entertainment centers and can be seen as large antennas on the top of your devices. You can also find them on live television studio broadcasts as well as on concert stages. The microphone booms on your TV help to track the movement of the performers on stage for the camera's best view. <n><n>#### D<n><n>### rationalisis:<n>The microphone boom may seem like a simple device but it plays a critical roll of keeping the audio clear, and helping maintain the audio level for the performer to deliver the vocals to the audience. Live events in general use microphone booms whether they are at a stadium for a sports event or in an auditorium for a stage performance..<n><n>#### E<n><n>### rationalis:<n>The microphone in a recording studio has to be able to move easily to capture all the tones from the vocalist as well as the bass and drums. When the microphone has to be at a different height or angle over a performance, the microphone needs to be able to move, hence the microphone boom.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>| Output Name       |  Output Type |  <n>| :-----------------:  | :----------  :  |

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:What happens to cats every day? Choices:  A: open doors B: drink water C: need food D: annoy E: play<n><n>### Response:		You are wrong, cats only do A and B, cats do not do C, D, and E<n>#### 4<n>Rationals: Cats do not do C and need food.<n>Cats don't need food and therefore, don't need to do D<n>Cats don'<n><n>### Input<n>**Rationals:<n>1. the first sentence is in the wrong tense. Change 'can' to 'can't'.<n>2. The second and third sentences are in the present continuous tense, but the 'doing word' is past. Change it to 'was doing'.<n>3. 'doing activity A', 'doing activity B', 'doing activity C' make things confusing. Use activity A and activity B and keep activity C to show that they are doing C in addition to A and B (because they don't switch).<n>4. there should be a comma after A.<n>5. Don't use a comma after 'is', but do use one after each item in the set ('does', 'was doing', 'was eating', 'was sleeping', and 'was playing').<n><n>**Response: No<n><n>Input: How many days in the week? Choice A: 7 B: 3 C: 6 D: 5 E: 10 F: other<n><n>### Response<n>**Rationals**<n>1. 'doesn't have a week number' is wrong (the week number is 1-54, so is always a number).<n>2. 'It doesn't have a day name that is always equal to its number.' is wrong, Saturday is always the 6th day.<n>3. 'There isn't one. We can only choose between seven and ten choices for the day.' make no sense (this sentence does not have much rationale).<n><n>### Response with Rationale<n>**Rationale**<n>1. Saturday is always the 7th day. So it counts towards 7 days in the week.<n>2. Sunday is either the 7th or 8th day. So it doesn't count towards 10, either.<n>3. Sundays, Mondays, and Tuesdays are all 1st through 3rd day of the week, respectively. They count towards 7 days.<n>4. Each of the other 5 days that start with

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:Sally was a senior in the House.  What might she be a member of? Choices:  A: assisted living facility B: old people's home C: high school or college D: republican party E: organization<n><n>### Response:		Choice is A: assisted living facilities because seniors live with a small group of others and their own staff.<n><n>### Output:<n>```<n>A<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>Terry eats 2 pounds of steak every day. How much does Terry weigh?<n><n>Answer 30<n>```<n><n>## Rationales<n>For 1 pound of steak, she eats 30 pounds of steak, and she weighs 14lbs because it's 14 times 30, and 14 times 14 times 2 gives you 30.<n><n><n>### 21st Century Skills<n>Students solve real-world problems by demonstrating and using rationales for their answers and explain their reasoning.  <n><n>### ISTE Standard<n>Students use multi-modal expressive and receptive communication to effectively, creatively, and appropriately convey information about their experiences, responses, and needs<n><n>### CCSS<n>CCSS ELA 4.4.B<n>Construct arguments using precise claim(s), sound reasoning, and relevant and sufficient evidence.

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:No matter the background of the person, they should all be given what in applying for the job? Choices:  A: critical thinking B: congratulated C: equal opportunity D: compliments E: raffle tickets<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>Demonstration:<n><n>### Input - Evaluation Question<n>The above question is how to answer the input-evaluation question.<n><n>There are four options. The answer is option (C).<n><n>C = Compliments<n>A = critical thinking<n>B = congratulated (not equal opportunity, not raffle tickets)<n>E = raffle tickets (not equal opportunity,not congratulated, not critical thinking, not compliments)<n><n>### Input-Evaluation Task<n>Sometimes while evaluating the task it is not clear which answer is correct to the task.<n><n>The answer for the question is<n><n>Demonstrates a concept of the task to give correct answer.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:What happens to the next appointment when a grooming takes longer than expected? Choices:  A: injury B: beauty C: late D: mistakes E: annoyed<n><n>### Response:		The next appointment is skipped.

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:Where would you stand in a line and need a coat if it is cold? Choices:  A: graph B: bank at noon C: good book D: post office E: bus stop<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Rationales:The place A,B,C, D is not the answer of the question. The book is not a coat.<n><n>### Answers:E<n><n>## Task 2<n>### Below is an instruction that asks for multiple questions. For each question you must answer the parts (a). Write your answer to show your work, and your answers to parts (b) and (c).<n><n><!--- <n>Input:John walks along a one-meter segment of a race track. He runs at a constant speed on the curve of the track, but runs at an increasing speed on its end. He is walking straight when he passes the end of the track. How fast is he running when he passes the end?<n><n>----><n><n>### Instructions (solution 1 - 15)<n>* 1st. Find what John walked along the race track 1-meter segment,and the end of the track, that has 360 degree. Then walk from the two points, if you find John is walking straight and speed is constant, use 360 degree to determine whether John walked faster or slower than his speed <n>* 2nd. When you pass the end of the track to walk on straight, you also need to check how far did walked and whether you walked faster or slower than your speed, which need you to calculate the degrees you walked in last half of 360 degrees, where you need to add that degree to the degrees you walked before, so you can subtract those degrees from 360 degree<n><n>### For 1st question<n>![image](/assets/img/solution/test2_img1.png)<n>Answers: 360 degree+(((2*(π*t))+π**3)+ π**4)/360 degrees <n>((x+1)/[(pi*(x+1))]**3-1)/360degree <n>(1/[(pi*(x+3))]**3-1/360degree<n>Answer: 360 degrees+(((2*(pi*t))+pi**3)+ pi**4)/[pi*(x+3)]**3<n><n><!---<n><n>Input:John walktes along a <n><n>----><n>#### Solutions (Solution 16 -1
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:where do you typically find a trash can in the city? Since the tens digit is 1 you add 6, your answer is 9.<n>Output: The sum is $96$.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:John loves animals and he hates animal abuse.  Because of this, john is very careful about the places he goes.  Where might he avoid going? Choices:  A: pet store B: parking lot C: woodland D: north america E: park<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### John does not like animal abuse but he likes pets.<n>So he would not avoid going to the pet store<n>#### John does not want to visit where animals live.<n>So he would never go to the woodland<n>#### John can travel between 2 different continents while keeping his home to be in the USA.<n>So he would choose to only avoid going to North America<n>#### Parks are not necessarily known to be places with animal abuse.<n>So he is actually more likely to avoid parking lots than going to a park.<n><n>### Reveal:<n>#### A<n>#### B<n>#### C<n>So C is the best choice<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n>Input: It costs $417 to fly from New York to Shanghai. How much is a ticket from Shanghai to Sydney?<n>Demostration: <n><n>$417 = <<417>>417<n><n>#### 417<n>Answer: 417<n><n>Input: What is equal to 13 * 2?<n>Demonstration:<n>13 * 2=<<13*2>>13*2<n>The number 13 goes into 2<n>13 goes into 12<n>13<n>Therefore the answer is 26<n><n>#### 26<n>Answer: 26<n><n>Input: In the city of Chicago, a gallon of lemonade costs $2.99. How much does a gallon of lemondade cost in the state of Alaska?<n>Demostation:<n>Lemondade costs $2. 99*2=<<2.99*2>>2.99* 2<n>The number 2.99 goes into 2<n>2.99 goes intot 14.96<n>Then we can divide by 2.<n><n>#### 14.99<n>Answer: 14.9<n><n>### Instuctions<n>Demostrations(s)<n>If someone gets paid $13.68 at work and earns $3.74 in bonuses, how much did he make that day?<n>13.68 is 26<n>3=26<n>26 is 13.68*2=<<13

Answer the following multiple choice question:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: You plan to buy an item for $50, and the item has a 50% off sale on it.<n>Rationales: Multiply $50 and 0.5 the answer will be: <<50*0.5=25>>25<n>So the answer will be $75.<n>####75<n>Answer: $75<n><n>### A,B,C,D,E,F and G are 6 different tasks. If the system passes A (100%), would you have to complete one of B (84%), C (63%) or D (55%), or do you not need to complete any of these tasks?<n>```<n>You plan to buy an item :<n>A. Choices: 1: for $50, B. Choices: 2: for $25, C. Choices: 3: for $10,D. Choices: 4: for $30, E. Choices: 5: for $45, F. Choices: 6: for $60<n>Rationales:<n>Input: The item for $50.<n>Output: $75<n>You can get the answer by calculating 50 * 0.5 = 25<n>```<n><n>### For the B, C, and D, and F and G: Which set of variables will the system use to determine if a user has completed these tasks and has met the minimum passing score for B, C, and/or D?<n>```<n>For the B, C, D, and F and/or G: <n>1. B will be 84%, 2. C will be 63%, 3. D will be 55%, 4. F will be 77%, and 5. G will be 38%.<n>```<n><n>## Problem solotion<n><n>The following is a problem, which asks that you complete the code so that the code can be inserted into another Java file. Write the code that will take the values that are supplied and determine if the value will pass the minimum passing score for any

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:What do people do to pass time before they can use electronics when fly in airplane? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:If you see blinking lights in the air at night, what are you usually looking at? Choices:  A: carnival B: plane C: concert D: turned at night E: a penguin's bum<n><n>### Response:		 E<n><n>### Instructions:Rules: *All arithmetic expressions are entered in a single line.<n>*Negative signs should be provided in the brackets: [–1] instead of the sign – in front of the term.<n>*Say for which term “of” means that term dived by the other.<n>>For “divided equally” say instead simply “/”.<n>*All variables should be lowercased unless you are defining a whole new term (so it is NOT a variable)<n>>For example a variable could be named “theAnswer” but not “answer”<n>*Use words and punctuation when referring to a term (not just “that term”).<n>>For example say “That term” instead of “theterm”.<n>*Do not say “The following rules” or something like that. Instead say “Rules”<n>>We do not want to waste extra words so keep it simple<n>*Do not say expressions in brackets like “[1/2 1]”<n>*Instead of saying “The product of” or “The factor”, instead say “multiplied by”.<n>>“Factor” also means factorial in a mathematical way and you are doing arithmetic not a math problem<n>*A term, an operation and an expression are not the same thing.<n>>The input is just an expression, one part of which is a term.<n>>Rules just say what to do with the operation and term, but they do not say what to do with an expression.<n>>Rules apply to terms too, since they are expressions.<n>*Do not say "term (t)" (or "operation (o)" or "expression (e)") to indicate that something is a term.<n>*Instead say simply "t" (or "o" or "e") so the rules will understand that.<n><n>#### Rule #1:A term is an expression that contains no operations.<n>>If an expression is not in brackets then it is a term<n>**Examples:**<n>```1 2 3 ``` is a term<n>```4 -5 6 ``` is not a term<n>>>RATIONALE: It is a single expression, but there is an operation in it<n><n>##### Rule# 2:If a term has an operation in it then, for purposes of the rules, the operation is applied to the term and to nothing else.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:Sarah thought that she had been home all evening.  That meant that the only time to leave was when? Choices:  A: early morning B: day time C: night D: afternoon E: daytime<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>Sarah went home at around 7pm.  The only time to leave was that was after she went home until she left which is 6 pm that means that the only time to left is when it was after she got home and before she left.<n><n>```<n><n>Because they were home all the time therefore,<n>They didn't leave until 7pm.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:The child really wanted to teach his grandpa to read, he thought it was wrong that he had spent his whole life what? Choices:  A: ignore B: write C: learn new things D: illiterate E: having fun<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: The child really wanted to teach  his grandpa to read. <n>He thought it was wrong that  he had spent his whole  life ignorant. <n>The grandpa spent his whole life what. <n><n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input :<n>John is really good at math, when his friends ask for his help he always gladly does.<n><n>### Response :<n>Input:   John is really good at math. <n>He always gladly does. 10 <n><n>#### 10<n><n>Answer: 10 <n>

Choices:  A: compliments B: passing grade C: intellectual challenge D: sticker E: avoid pain<n><n>### Response:		<n>If the person is competent in their schoolwork, he/she is likely to expect pass grades, intellectual challenge, sticker, and avoid pain. He/she may also expect compliments. But not every time.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The person may not expect only pass grade but also the other 4 choices. For example, He/she may expect to avoid pain because he can’t cope with pain.<n>

Sometimes you will receive a task without a correct solution and have to work through your own solution.<n><n>D1) Given 6*2=<<6*2=12>>12, the difference is: 6*2-12=-<<6*2-1=10>>10.<n><n>D2) Given: 2/3*15=<<2/3*1=15>>15, the difference is:<n>3*(2/3-1) = 3*-<<2/3+1>>=3*(1-2/3)= <<3*(1-2 3)/6>><n><n>### Helpful Hints:<n>You don't always need to divide the entire sentence for a task. If the sentence says that you have to do something, you could simply solve the task by substituting or replacing something.<n><n>For example, given that 3+2=<<3+2=5>>5. We can simply solve it by replacing 3 with 2 and 2 with 3.<n><n>#### Task<n>D1) What is one half of 3?<n><n>#### Task with Solution

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:He called bull when his friend said a bull can be what? Determining whether or not the statement is true or false tells us if the idea we have in mind in our head is what the statement describes.<n><n>#### True<n>Answer:True<n><n>### Instuction #2:<n>What are examples of how you can write the multiplication and division of positive and negative numbers?<n><n>### Demo:<n>Rationales:(+) (&times;) = (*) - (- * &times; &times;) = &sect; (&sect;)<n><n>Explanation: (&times;) means Multiply and (*) means Multiply by<n><n>Answer:<n>### Instuctions:<n>Complete the task. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:James drove his niece to her father.  Where did he drive? Choices:  A: great granddad's house B: family picture book C: brother's house D: family tree E: family reunion<n><n>### Response:		Choce D: family tree<n><n>### Reasoning:  Family tree represents the tree-like diagram. It shows ancestral members of a family, including their family relations with other members in the tree. All family trees consist of the "first generation", the "second generation", etc., showing the direct descendants of one person and their spouse from the earliest generation back to the earliest ancestor with documentation.

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:Where would you find a desk normally occupied by a young person? Choices:  A: office building B: schoolroom C: library D: bedroom E: gym<n><n>### Response:		The correct answers are desk, schoolroom, and library.<n><n>### Why:A desk is a flat table or platform used for working at.<n>Because in schools, pupils and students use desks when doing their work.<n>And libraries are buildings in which books and magazines are housed and they also where people read on desks.<n>And in a gym, you can find desks if the gym has office furniture, or if you play a card based game.<n>The correct options then are: A: office building(Because desks are mostly found in offices)<n>B: schoolroom(Because students use desks when they are reading and studying)<n><n>### Challenge<n><n>### Demonsatration:<n>Input: 1st grade students at Lakeside Elementary went from 149.2 lbs all the way up to 178 lbs this past month - an impressive 28.8 pounds in 6 weeks! How many "how much" questions might contain a mistake?<n>#### 250<n>Answer: 250<n><n>### Response-"What might you" question.  What's a "what might you" question?<n>#### Choice A:  How many "what might you" questions are there?<n>#### Choice B:  A "What might you" is also called a how many question.<n>#### Choice C:  How can you tell what type of questions are what might you questions?<n>#### Choice D:  What do we want answers to?<n>#### Choice E:  What is one type of questions that is asked during an interview. <n><n>#### Choice A<n>#### Choice B<n>#### Choice C<n>#### Choice D<n>#### Choice E<n><n>### Response -"What type" questions.  What "what does it cost" questions have to do with "how many"? <n>#### Choice A is correct, but we want to know what 42 out of 65 are correct.  We are given 250 <n>#### Choice B is correct, but we don't want to know just how many, we want what 42 are correct, <n>#### Choice C is correct, these are also called "How many or what" <n>#### Choice D is correct and is part of this response's answer. <n>#### Choice E is correct, these are another type of questions asked during an interviw-<n><n>#### Choice D (not A)<n>#### Choice D and E (not A or B)<n><n>## #151<n>## ##153<n>## ##154<n><n>### Instructions:  Write a sentence that expresses the answer to each multiple choice question.   <n>### Demonstaton: Input::<n>What is 7+7? <n><n>Output: 1

Choices:  A: free time B: pleasure C: get divorced D: legal fees E: being lonely<n><n>### Response:		 legal fees<n><n>### Explanation:<n>When both spouses want a divorce, the divorce fees are what they call legal fees of a costly task.<n><n>### <n><n>###  Input:You are an undergraduate student at the University of Texas.  You have a $500 scholarship that is awarded to only 15 top applicants to your program. Out of 900 freshmen applicants this year, you are not one of the 15 awarded the 500 scholarship. How many more applicants need to be considered for the scholarship to have a 15% chance of receiving it?<n>Rationales:(1000 * 6/7)/ 250 = <<1000 *6/7>250/500>>500.<n>So out of 900 applicants, the answer has to go through the division 1000 * /6/250 = <<900 *6/>250>> 900*6<n>That means the answer has to be 900 * 6 = <<900*6=5400>>5400.<n>So there are 5400 applicants, you need to find out the 5400/ 900 = <<5400/100>> 5400/(100/900) >> 5400 (100/9) = <<540/540>>540/5<n>So 540/5 = <<540*5=2700>>2700.<n>So 2700 /540 = <<2700*540>>5/2700 = <<5/270>>270/5<n>So, the answer is 270/540 =<<270/5>3\4>> 5/4 =<<5/4=1\2>>1\2.<n>#### 1\2<n><n>###  Answer: 1\2<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:What will happen if you are successful when committing suicide? Choices:  A: scars B: being born C: sorrow D: misery E: kill yourself<n><n>### Response:		The letter "D" is a synonym of "KILL YOURSELF." So the response is "A" scars, "B" being born, and "C" sorrow.

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:A school is most likely to be located in what sort of zone? Choices:  A residential neighborhood Bcommunity C building D prague  E every  city<n>Rationale for Choice A<n>1. Residential neighborhood<n>2. Neighborhoods in cities are more or less residential, so a school is more likely to be found there.<n>Rationales for Choices B-D<n>1. Community: Communities usually include a hospital, school, library, fire station, etcetera.<n>2. Building: Usually the most accessible type of building is a school, because it’s the most important.<n>Rationale for Choices E<n>1. Every city: Because every city needs a school.<n>#### A: residential neighborhood

D: gym E: theatre<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input:John and Joe are talking to each other<n>John: "I'm going to the movies with my friends. It's probably gonna be a really exciting movie."<n>Joe: "Okay. That sounds good. What do you think you'll learn from it?"<n>Rationales:"I'm going to" indicates a present plan or activity<n>"it's probably" means they're not sure if it's going to happen<n><n>"What do you think you're going to learn from it" asks for information about specific details<n>#### "I don't know what happened" vs. "I'm not sure"<n>Input: The man said, "I don't understand what you're saying."<n>Rationale: The word "understand" is an action verb, so we cannot use "not"<n>Demostration:We do not need to provide a response, but if we were, we would have said this:<n><n>### Response to the above question:<n><n>### Input example: Tom wants to ask a question<n><n>### Response example:<n><n>### Instuction:<n><n>### Demo example:Input: John had 6 dogs<n>Rationales:The sentence "he had" uses "have" as the auxiliary verb. In this case, John has dogs, not dog, so "had" should be used<n>### Input example 2: John had 5 apples and he had 5 oranges<n>Rationales:John has all 5 of the apples that he currently has<n>He has all 5 oranges that he currently has<n>### Instruction for part 2<n><n>### A. Mrs. Brown loves ice cream<n>Rationales:To love something requires a quality of affinity towards that thing<n>A thing cannot "love" something else. Mrs. Brown is loving ice cream.<n>### D. She is going to buy dinner at the pizza store tonight for the family.<n>Rationales:She is going to buy dinner as an action at the pizza store. The pizza store is not doing something on its own.

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:What does someone chatting with friends do when they hear a joke? Choices:  A: giggle B: lie C: laughing D: chuckle E: smoke<n><n>### Response:		The best option is C.<n><n>### Reason: a) Because giggle means "to laugh in a happy way," so the speaker would chuckle. B. Because Lie means "to tell someone that what you say is untrue," so the speaker would not speak to the joke.<n>So options a, b, and d are wrong and options c and e are right.<n><n>### 14<n>Answer: 14<n><n>### Instructions: Write a program that adds two arrays<n>Input 1:<n>```<n>73 41 1 37 20 58 12 23 77 12 84 0 21<n>```<n><n><n>Input 2:<n>```<n>48 95 52 0 11 74 17 83 45 61 68 2 56<n>```<n><n>### Output:<n>```<n>79 59 1<n>```<n><n>`Note: The output should be the sum of the two arrays.`<n><n>### Solution:<n><n><n>```<n>int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {<n>	int a[numInArray], b[numInArray];<n>	double sum;<n><n>	scanf("%d",&numInArray);<n>	for(int i=0; i<numInArray;i++){<n>		scanf("%d ",a+i);<n>	}<n><n>	for(int j=0; j<numInArray;j++){<n>		if(j==0){<n>			scanf("%[^\n]", &b[j]);<n>		}<n>		else{<n>			scanff("%d ", &b[j]); //1st element is a<n>		}<n><n>	}<n><n><n>	for(i=0;i<2; i++){<n>		for(j=0;j<2;j++){<n>	<n>	sum=0;<n>	sum=a[i]+b[j];<n><n>	}<n>		printf("%d ",sum);	<n><n>	}<n>}<n>	main (argc, argv);<n>```<n><n>## Instruction:<n>Input: Enter up to 10 numbers<n>Find the smallest and enter

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:What state shaped like a glove has a lot of farmland? Choices:  A: countryside B: farming areas C: michigan D: texas E: north dakota<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Explanation:The answer to this question is North Dakota.<n><n>### Input What language is spoken in china in 2016? Choices:  a: english b: french c: chinese <n>### Response:c<n><n>### Explination:china is made of asia and a little bit of europe so english would not be spoken in china<n><n>### Input 3.21 divided by 2.11<n>### Response 1.511<n>### Explanaton<n>because 3.21/ is 1.51<n>so 1.51 + 0.51 = 1.51 *1.51 = 2.29 -> 2.29/2.11 = 1.o8<1.3>0.59 -> 0.59/0.51 =1.17<n><n>### Input the square root of 29<n>### Response 5<n>### Explanotion<n>so 5*4 = 20 because 2*2 = 4<n>### Input the area of a rectangle that is 3.5 cm wide and that is 3.3 cm high.<n>### Response 4.703 cm<n>### Explanoton<n>because area of a rectangle = width*heigth = 3.5*3.3 = 11.75 cm<n> 4.702 rounded up would be 5<n><n>### Input how many yards are in 580 feet<n>### Response 200 yards<n>### Explanitation<n>580 feet divided by 6 = 95 <n>### Input what was the final score of last nights game? The game score was 7-1.<n>### Response the the score of 7 and 1 for a total of 8<n>### Explanution<n>the total score is 7+1 = 8<7+1=8><n>### Input a 120 word text is 2 pages. What is the length of a 80 page paper?<n>### Response 8 pages<n>### Explaniton<n>8 *2 = 16<n>### Input How many hours is 1
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:If you harm property after starting a fire where are you likely to end up? Choices:  A: damage B: going to jail C: going to school D: burns E: destruction<n><n>### Response:		<n>If this is an instruction where you are given a response to choose from or if there is a picture the you are to choose the one that best demonstrates the answer for example you are given the choice of a picture that shows something is wrong with a car you would simply choose the one that clearly shows the problem by looking at the picture.If this is a math problem you are to simply show the solution.<n><n>### Reason:<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>Reason: Reason given in the first paragraph of the assignment.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>A: The word that is most likely to explain why the person is in jail is damage. Damage is harm that a fire causes. We see a fire burning a wooden house. If a person starts a fire at a wooden house and then damages the house to a point where he or she might have to be taken to jail, then the damage is the word that best explains what has happened. <n><n>B: The word that best explains where the person will be taken when he or she is hurt as a result of the fire is going to jail. Going to jail is the most likely sentence for most serious fire damage. The fire burning down a house is enough damage to land the offender in jail. Hence, going to jail is the best word to explain what is likely to happen.<n><n>C: A fire could injure someone or even kill the person. However, the injury that results from a fire burns. As such, the only burns that might result from a fire are the burns.  If there are burns, then the person is expected to visit a doctor to ensure he or she is medically fit before returning to school. As such, the word best explains what happens to someone who is hurt in a fire. Hence, burns is a fitting word to use in this case.<n><n>D: The word best explains what happens when you cause harm to someone or to their property. The harm is destruction. As such, the harm to the home after a fire caused by setting a house could result in the offender getting sent to jail. However, in such a case, the fire damage would lead to the destruction of the house due to the fire. <n><n>E: Destruction causes harm. Harm happens with fire. We see that a fire causes harm to the people whose houses are destroyed. So, a fire could cause
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:A person is alone in the woods and wounded, what should he do? Choices:  A: amount to nothing B: visit relatives C: charming D: doctor himself E: cross street<n><n>### Response:		<n>I will answer that choosing C or D is good enough.<n><n>### Reasons:<n>* In A, it is not a good choice to leave the person alone, that may cause more problems and eventually lead to their death, when they can still make it to a hospital, why wait for more.<n>*  In B, it is not a very wise move to just leave the person alone and not give a second thought. It is good to contact relatives so they can be there for you when you and your family is in need.<n>* In D, self medication or just doing what you want won't give you a solution, or give a better result to be honest. The patient needs to have their wound tended to properly so it will not deterriere. If that is not done, then that will only give more injuries.<n><n>### A:<n>A: amount to nothing<n><n>### B:<n>B: visit relatives<n><n>### C:<n>C: charming<n><n>### D:<n>D: doctor himself<n><n>### E:<n>E: cross street<n>

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day. Choices:  A: attic B: basement C: art show D: church E: bar<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:  C<n>Rationales: A-attic:  A wine cellar or wine room is a room constructed underground, generally in a basement, cellar, or an area of a kitchen, or even in a garden specifically made to store wine.<n>B-basement:  Wine storage is the practice of storing wine properly, most commonly in a wine cellar, also known as a cave. It is not only a matter of climate and the appropriate storage conditions. The storage system is important, as is the packaging.<n>C-Artshow:  For a wine cellar, art collection, or other collectible items a room or building designed especially for the display of these can be called an art show or collection.<n>D-Church:  Wine is used in many Christian ceremonies, so there are many special wine storage rooms in churches.<n>E-Bar :  This is where I store bottle openers....  not wine.. lol<n><n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input:-1+1.0<n><n>### Answer:-0.9<n><n>### Rationale:-1+1.2= <<1+1.2 =1.2>>1.2 since they add up to 2, and they are the same numbers<n><n>### Rational:-1+1.1666=<<1+1.1=1.2>>1<n><n>### Answer:1<n><n>### Input :-20<n><n>### Ration:-1-0.5=<<1-0.5 =0.5>>0.5<n><n>### Answer :-15<n><n>### Instructions:  Use the equation, 9+5*2.9-3+6-2.4+3=<<9+5*2*9=45>>45 to answer the following multiple choice question <n><n>#### 46<n>Answer: 46<n><n>### Input :-9.5+4.5<n><n>##Rational:-10+6=<<10+6 =16>>16<n><n>###Answer:-16<n><n>## <n>Input: <<10>> and <<10>><n>Rationales:<n><n>10*10=<<10*10 =100>>100<n><n>Input: <<

Choices:  A: efficiency B: getting work done C: marriage D: finishing up E: results<n><n>### Response:		I found answers on the internet <n>https://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/getting-married-how-long-do-you-need-20767.html<n><n>### Result:<n>https://www.quora.com/How-long-do-boudoir-photoshoots-typically-last <n>```<n>Boudoir shoots are typically anywhere from one to three hours. The amount of time depends upon the shoot goal, the photographer, your confidence level, the time of day, and any poses or stylings. Many photographers charge by the hour for boudoir. <n>```<n>### Input:An 21 yo college coed took a job at the hospital as a medical assistant. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:Where would someone be likely to store a double edge razor? Choices:  A: pocket B: shower C: chemist D: drug store E: shaving kit<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. [E]: Shaving kit<n><n><n>

A student bought 3 books and 6 DVDs. What was the total cost of her purchases?<n>Rationales : For the books, we multiply for her 30 dollars, because the cost of the books is 30 dollars, so the answer is 3 * 30 = <<3*30=90>>90, which can be rounded.<n><n>For the DVD's, her 6 DVD's cost her 60 dollars, because the DVD cost 60 dollars. The total cost for her purchases was 90+60 = <<90+60=150>>150, which can also be rounded.<n><n>Total Cost: <<150>>100<n><n>**Input** : Where would you put a computer? Your answer is seventy.<n><n>### Rationales<n>First write down the bottle prices for all the wine and water.<n><n>\$ 4.5 Bottles of Red Wine = $ 4.5 Bx 10 = 45<n><n>\$ 1.5 Bottles White Wine = $ 1.5 Bx 9 = 13.5<n><n>\$3.5 Bottles Sparkling Water = $3.5x9 = 31.5<n><n>$$45 + 13.5 +  31.5   =70$$<n><n>The price for one bottle of wine is ten dollars.<n><n>So the product of 70x10 = 700.<n><n>However, we are buying 4.5 bottle of wine.<n><n>So 4.5(70x10) = 299.5<n><n>In 1 case, we spent $299.5.<n><n>#### 700<n>Answer: 700<n><n>### Input :<n>A man paid three times that amount for a jacket than his friend pays for a sweater. If all those career fields were put in order by the most possible and the least possible, in that order would be as follows:<n><n>endodontist<n>professor<n>dentist<n>scientist<n>student<n><n>1) He cannot be a scientist and an endodontist<n>because of order which states to go with the most possible and the less possible.  He also cannot be a dentist and also an endodontist because that comes after the professor and is before the dentist.  He can be a professor and a dentist because these two come right after professor.<n>

How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:Where can you find pamphlets regarding diseases and ailments? Choices:  A: theaters B: health department C: library D: drawer E: mail box<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### C<n>Answer:  C<n>### Input:Choose an option from the drop-down menu. <n>#### A<n>Choices:  a) a play b) a movie c) a theater production d) a theater show<n>#### D<n>Choices:  d) the theater, e) both theater production and theater <n>### Response: Choose D to remove any other unwanted food you ordered<n>#### D<n>Answer:  D<n><n>---<n><n>### Input Choose the appropriate choice for the following sentence.<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### A<n>Choice: A<n>#### A<n>Choose Choice: A<n>### Response<n>### C<n><n>#### C<n>Choice: C<n>### C<n>Choose C to continue.<n>### C<n>Response<n>#### C<n>Answer C<n><n>---<n><n><n>### Input The following sentences may be correct but may be incorrect.   Find the correction if needed.<n><n>### Demo: Correct: If a child has food allergies, parents  should speak to a doctor.<n><n>### Correct: If a child eats an orange, the child will feel good.   <n><n>### Demo2: Correction: If a child eates an orange, the child may like the taste.<n><n>### Correction: If the price of tomatoes goes up, my grandma will buy more. <n><n>### Demo3: Correction:  If a childs stomach hurts after eating a tomato, the child should drink more milk.<n><n>### Incorrect: If the price goes up, I will  buy less food. <n><n>## Demo4: If it is sunny out, I won't wear a jacket.<n><n>## Demo5: If I don't go shopping, I won't have food when I  need it.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:What animal produces milk? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:What would cause someone to use invitro for reproducing? Choices:  A: problems B: offspring C: overpopulation D: larger family E: baby<n><n>### Response:		<n>I would go with D, I think we could say larger family is a side effect, I would say B is more accurate.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:Sally took her medicine and experienced strong side effects. At the same time, it is making good use of its money and is expected to continue to bring high returns to its owners.<n><n>### What is meant in question I by rapid rate? This is a good sign that the business is doing well and can be taken by customers and they are earning profit. However there are some problems when a business grows fast. When a business grows the employees may experience problems that occur from change in job structure and management. This may lead to a decline of profit as employees are not satisfied with their job. The employees may resign and leave the company.<n><n>### How was the business doing when it was established? At first the business was doing very good. The employees were happy and the owner was also happy because he was earning profit. Everything was going well at the time of establishing the company.<n><n>#### 5<n><n>### How does the company make use of its money? The company makes use of its money to bring high returns to owners. The company uses its money to invest for the company as it is known to be a long term investment. It is an essential to the business to spend the money on employees as they are the most important assets of the business. For example they are the ones who work and contribute to the profit of the company.<n><n>The company is taking its profit to the right extent. It is a sign of good management. The management and employees are doing a good job in increasing the profit. Due to the fact that there are many firms around them that might take the customers away and they will not only make profit but also earning. He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:Why would someone confess to committing murder? Choices:  A: guilty conscience B: fear C: go free D: problems E: find god<n><n>### Response:		How could I ask why someone would confess to committing a murder? <n><n>### Choice A: guilty conscience.<n>```javascript<n>    {guilty conscience}<n>```<n><n>### Choices B: fear<n>```javascript<n>    [fear]<n>```<n><n>## Task Instructions<n><n>### Choose the letter of the BEST choice.<n>#### Fear, problem, go free, confess, committing, conscience, problems?<n><n>**Note:** The solution isn't always the best option.<n><n>### Choosing the letter of the BEFOST Choice:<n>#### guilty conscience, fear, 9/11, freedom fighter<n><n>### Question:<n>Answer the following multiple choice(either/or) question.<n><n>## Answer the following multiple choice question:<n>I have lost my house and car.<n><n>Choices: A: I have lost my house and cars<n>B: I have lost my car and house<n><n>C:I have lost both my house and car in the fire.<n><n>D:I have lost a few of my personal belongings.<n><n>### Answer:<n>I have lost both my cars and house<n><n>### Answer the following multiple choice(or/nor) question:<n>My cousin is in love with a girl.<n><n>Choices A:My cousin has had a wonderful relationship with the girl.<n>B: My brother has had a sad relationship with the girl. <n><n>C:My cousin has a had a wonderful relationship with a girl who likes him back. <n><n>D:My brother's relationship is so sad he can no longer be in love with her.<n><n>### C:My cousin has had an wonderful relationship with a girl <n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:Danny hated helping people.  It always brought what? Choices:  A: satisfaction B: good feelings C: complications D: feel good about yourself E: stress<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration<n>Input: The time to solve the problem should be less than<n>Rationales: The answer is that the time is less than or equal to 1.<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Note: This request has many different possible valid answers, <n>not just the single answer.<n><n>### Input What are the rules about the use of the word or?<n><n>### Response<n>The word or means that one of the options are good, it is an option between two choices. <n><n>#### 1, 2, or 5<n>Answer: 1, 2 or 5<n><n>### Input Choose one:<n><n>### Response One way to find the sum of five and six is to add up all of their factors.<n><n>#### 3 5 and 1 are all the factors<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Instructors Note:<n>Above request asks a student to use all the factors, and the correct explanation has been listed below:<n>```<n>First student should determine each number’s factors as seen in the table given.<n><n><n>|<n>6=3+3<n>5=2+2+3<n>5+6=12=3*2+4=3*2+3+2=4*2+3<n>5^2=25=25-1=5*(24)<n><n>Then<n><n>sum of 5^2 and 6=25+3=28<n>```<n>## Demonstrate: The average of four numbers is 15.<n><n>### Response 5, 15, 23, and 24, all equal 99<n><n>### Instractor's Note:<n>The given answer has been written in an incorrect order which results in incorrect final result:<n>```<n>The following table has the 4 numbers in correct order.<n><n>4 numbers in order: 24<n><n>|<n>24=20+4<n><n>23<n><n>15<n><n>5<n>```<n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:What is something you do  in a bank? Choices:  A: make noise B: have tea C: make time D: make payments E: take time<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: A<n><n>#### A<n>I like to make noise at banks. I'll scream and ask for service, sometimes when the teller isn't ready to see me<n><n>### Response #2:<n>Input: C<n><n>#### C<n>I like to make time in banks.  I usually walk into a bank, stand in the middle of the room with my arms crossed and then I say to no one in particular 'Hmm. Time is funny these days. And I am in a dilemma about my time.'<n><n>### Response 3:<n>Input: A or B or C<n><n>#### B<n>I like to have tea at the bank.  I like to order an Earl Grey Latte and sit in one of the comfortable chairs they have set up for customers to enjoy their beverages from.  In these chairs I can get up and sit down, or walk around and think about the time I am losing.<n><n>### Response to response #1:<n>This is not a valid type of answer.<n><n>### 24<n>Answer:<n>

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.
